document_title: Lupus nephritis: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis, prevention
subsection_content:
Current world medicine still cannot completely treat lupus nephritis. Treatments only help reduce symptoms, slow disease progression, and reduce the risk of dialysis and kidney transplant. Depending on each person's medical condition, the doctor may prescribe medications such as:
Corticosteroids: Medicines that reduce inflammation. Doctors often prescribe use until the inflammation improves. However, the drug has some serious side effects. Therefore, patients need to use medication exactly as directed by the doctor.; Immunosuppressive drugs: Azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, voclosporin, mycophenolate... can inhibit the activity of the immune system, causing damage to the kidneys.; Medications to control blood pressure: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) help prevent protein from leaking from the kidneys into the urine.; Medicines to prevent blood clot formation (if needed).; Even with treatment, loss of kidney function may continue to develop. If drug treatment is no longer effective, the doctor may prescribe dialysis. This method helps remove fluid and waste from the body, maintain balance of minerals in the blood, and control blood pressure.
If medical treatment is not effective, the doctor may prescribe dialysis
A kidney transplant is often the final treatment for people with lupus nephritis.
